title: Which show will win the Emmy for "Outstanding Drama Series"?
preds: Although I have not seen all of the shows, I know the one always talked about is Game of Thrones. I am therefore predicting that GOT will win Outstanding Drama Series like the year prior.

I changed my mind, the strongholds of »The Americans«, namely television critics and cineasts on http://www.goldderby.com/article/2016/gold-derby-tv-awards-2016-winners-people-v-oj-simpson-game-of-thrones-news-913752468/ revealed their preferences in a vote last month that undermined the very notion of what they were promoting.

The writing and directing races at the Emmys often foretell what’ll win the top program prizes. “Game of Thrones” leads its competitors with two directing bids and one in writing. “Downton Abbey” (66/1 odds) is the only other drama series contender to appear in both of these key categories. “Mr. Robot” (33/1 odds) contends in writing while “Homeland” (80/1 odds) pops up in directing. Does that mean “House of Cards” (66/1 odds) and “Better Call Saul” (100/1 odds) are out of this race completely? The last time a show won Best Drama Series at the Emmys without either a writing or directing bid was “The Practice” in 1999. http://www.goldderby.com/article/2016/emmy-awards-best-drama-series-game-of-thrones-the-americans-news-1357924680-2/ GOT has 75% chance to win.
http://gameofthrone.net/uncategorized/how-likely-is-game-of-thrones-to-win-at-the-emmys-weve-got-odds/
Game of Thrones is the subject that EVERYONE talks about these days.

HoC is not twice as likely to win than Homeland, as they are about equally as unlikely. While the other shows are all highly praised, GoT is likely to submit one of its final two episodes of the season, which from technical, directorial, and writing standpoints are universally praised and high marks in TV for both their expenses and scope.

GoT is the reigning winner and the heavy favorite to repeat this year after a compelling season. Mr. Robot is being nominated for the first time, so there is no previous data as to how it will fair in the field. Mr. Robot and the Americans are both in the next tier of candidates as the both are highly praised shows with buzz around both. Mr. Robot gets a slight edge based on the uncertainty of how it will fair in its first year of nomination. Downton Abbey will garner some votes as it finished its final season and has been perennially nominated without winning. Better Call Saul has some favorability based on the academy's love of its predecessor Breaking Bad. Homeland and House of Cards have seen mixed reviews. House of Cards finished its final season, which gives it a slight edge over previous winner Homeland.
Reckon it is between The Americans, Game of Thrones, and Downtown Abbey.  Think The Americans gets the nod this year, it is finally getting "mainstream" praise.
By mistake had put 85% on Downton Abbey instead of Game of Thrones.

Emmy voters only watch a handful of handpicked episodes, here they are: The Americans     “Chloramphenicol,”
    “Travel Agents,”
    “The Magic of David Copperfield V,”
    “The Day After,”
    “A Roy Rogers in Franconia,” and
    “Persona Non Grata.” Better Call Saul     “Gloves Off,”
    “Rebecca,”
    “Bali Ha’i,”
    “Fifi,”
    “Nailed,” and
    “Klick.” Downton Abbey     “Episode 6.01,”
    “Episode 6.03,”
    “Episode 6.06,”
    “Episode 6.07,”
    “Episode 6.08,” and
    “Episode 6.09.” Game of Thrones     “The Red Woman,”
    “Home,”
    “Oathbreaker,”
    “Book of the Stranger,”
    “Battle of the Bastards,” and
    “The Winds of Winter.” Homeland     “The Tradition of Hospitality,”
    “Why Is This Night Different?,”
    “All About Allison,”
    “The Litvinov Ruse,”
    “Our Man in Damascus,” and
    “A False Glimmer.” House of Cards     “Chapter 40,”
    “Chapter 41,”
    “Chapter 42,”
    “Chapter 43,”
    “Chapter 44,” and
    “Chapter 45.” Mr Robot     “eps1.0_hellofriend.mov,”
    “eps1.1_ones-and-zer0es.mpeg,”
    “eps1.5_br4ve-trave1er.asf,”
    “eps1.7_wh1ter0se.m4v,”
    “eps1.8_m1rr0r1ng.qt,” and
    “eps1.9_zer0-day.avi.”

The vote process described: http://www.thewrap.com/emmy-ballots-heres-what-happens-next-28041/ - the show nominees chose six episodes
- Emmy's are handed out based on single, or few, episodes; not story arcs and the season
- at home, volunteers write down a first-second-third ranking
- by point scores, the winner might have consistently ranked second, but get the few necessary nods against the others.
================
Just like GJO: effort and commitment is crucial ... "6 episodes x 45-minute running times x 6 nominees = more than 25 hours of viewing." But since they watch it at home, they can skip the work. For some reasons, nominees without a writing nomination tend to lose. Maybe they see the nominations list and simply don't consider them anymore. - Saul (got really good critical reviews, but no nomination!)
- Homeland
- Cards Remainder: + The Americans
+ Downton Abbey
+ Game of Thrones
+ Mr. Robot

These are damn good shows. Zero chance is not really zero chance. Better Call Saul  hasn't yet gotten "the" major traction. Downtown Abbey, though still finely tuned, has run its course, and will be in syndication forever. House of Cards - a Splash onto the scene a couple years back, and still with a loyal following....and maybe too scary reality, given this political season (ha-ha). Mr. Robot - super edgy, but too weird for many. The Americans - Spy genre is haute cuisine these days.  The increased dynamics imposed by the children getting older is adding heft, but the show is a little toooo fake-y. I mean really, a moustache or a wig and EVERYBODY thinks you look like another person. Homeland - in the current wheelhouse for Spy genre and lot more sophisticated and real than The Americans. Claire Daines nails the part (as does Patinkin aka Saul), but sometimes, this show also pushes too much of the believability landscape. But she and Saul are forever loyal and they are always thinking steps ahead.......reasonable chance to win. Game of Thrones -- I don't know anyone who doesn't watch it and isn't waiting for the next episode. Each character is masterfully developed, and the plot lines intricately connect. Nobody is above The Law of Karma. Sets are imaginative. Costumes and Realms match the characters and places. (Jon's death could be argued, but the setting is an imaginative, mystical world, so more precedence than a wig change that confuses everyone.)

An internet search on predictions showed that the Game of Thrones is a favourite, although they were rather thin on supporting arguments. There was a remark about being a precedence for the same series to win a number of times in consecutive years.  Another remark found in this site was that if the consensus (on this site) is for the GoT then that in itself is an indication that it will win. However, the number of forecasters (73) is probably too small and those who participate on this site can hardly be considered a representative sample. It appears that there is a significant financial reward in winning an Emmy [Source: http://fortune.com/2015/09/22/emmy-awards-value-worth/  and http://www.forbes.com/sites/dorothypomerantz/2014/09/03/emmy-awards-come-with-a-heavy-dose-of-piracy/#32f96dfb2862], but from then on it appears to be a black box, i.e. what a series needs to have to win. Notably a quick look over the other choices on this site showed a much higher variability, perhaps suggesting individual preferences.
Based entirely on consensus, but this is a question about popular taste. Consensus should always be right on this kind of question.
My personal favourite is the americans.

Game of Thrones has virtually owned social media during its reign. This season has sparked continued viewing and high amounts of illegal viewings. It's insanely popular. Mr. Robot is in the running for its superb acting and plot line while providing a stark contrast from GoT. The other shows don't offer much in the way of competition and haven't garnered the outpouring of the public as they are all continued stories (like GoT) with a fan base, but lack the polish of Mr. Robots story telling.

Lowering forecast for "The Americans" based on  @ts2m http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/297304 about viewer population as well as info in link 1.
Increasing "Mr. Robot" based on link 1 & the fact that it is also a strange (bizarre) and offbeat tale and may be developing a cult-like following.      Game of Thrones forecast as most likely winner...summary of story updates provided routinely in US & UK newspapers! 1:  http://www.indiewire.com/2016/07/2016-emmy-predictions-outstanding-drama-series-63808/
I am working very hard at trying to care about this, since all of these programmes appear to be unalloyed crappe.  However, one soldiers on.

Here is the twist: "The Americans,” starring Keri Russell and Matthew Rhys, is the best show on television that no one is watching." [1] The contender is "Better Call Saul". Asking profession reviewers, they all would say that "The Americans" is the better show, but only a niche segment was watching it. In the list of past Emmy nominees, there was at least one other "best show on television" -- with spotless critical praise -- and nobody watched; a series called "Deadwood". [3] It drew the best 9 in 10 points from too few critical reviewers and too few lucky TV watchers; so it "Lost" the Emmy to JJ Abrams' season 1, that year. This year's "The Americans" received spotless (professional) critical praise, too! [1] Unlike Deadwood, more critical reviewers cared to say something, too, with some more fans.  However, "Eric Schrier, FX’s president . . . , who explained that the nature of the series made it inherently niche." [1] Marketers seem to hide its ratings, otherwise you would find them prominently displayed on Wikipedia. "Of the nearly 2.4 million viewers who tuned in to Season 3 on average, over 1.3 million of them were over 50 years old; fewer than 250,000 viewers between the ages of 18 and 34 were watching. [The core advertising market is 18 to 49.] In fact, no season of “The Americans” has ever averaged over a million viewers 18 to 34 years old. Season 1 came the closest with 795,000. Younger viewers, it seems, are just not all that interested in the Cold War." [1] Season 4 "kicked off on March 16, 2016, and its debut drew 1.11 million viewers" [4] "Better Call Saul", on the other hand, opened with 2.6 million within the core market. [5] It received spotless critical praise, too, and maintained a 2-million average viewership. No other Emmy nominee has spotless elevated critical reviews. The question is whether the jury panel tilts towards a sinister spy series for the old, or a sinister gangster for the young? [1] http://www.ibtimes.com/americans-reaches-season-4-why-more-people-are-not-watching-why-fx-does-not-care-2337931 [2] http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-americans/season-4 [3] http://www.metacritic.com/tv/deadwood/season-2 [4] http://release-date.info/tv-series/the-americans-season-5-release-date-789300234/ [5] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Better_Call_Saul#Ratings A note on "Game of Thrones"; in this years Oscars, "Revenant" was hugely popular, yet lost to "Spotlight".
I personally would give it to Better Call Saul... Not giving everything to GoT because there is a strange respect among critics for The Americans and even stranger one for Mr Robot.
Outstanding series and the last season was the best of all. I think none of the other series could beat them.
